newsitem.title: USA: Canadian spot natgas prices edge higher on NYMEX.
newsitem.headline: Canadian spot natgas prices edge higher on NYMEX.

text.p: Canadian natgas prices rose slightly Monday in response to the higher opening on NYMEX and a strong storage injection demand, traders said.
Spot gas at the AECO storage hub in Alberta was quoted at C$1.55/1.58 per gigajoule, up an average of two cents from Friday.
"I think it's up a little on the back of NYMEX," a Calgary-based trader said.
NYMEX's July Henry Hub natgas futures rose to a high of $2.18 earlier today, up 3.1 cents from Friday's session.
July and July/October AECO were also talked firmer at C$1.56 per MWh.
A trader noted that storage injections in Alberta totalled 1.2 billion cubic feet (bcf) on Saturday and one bcf on Sunday.
However, he said he expected storage injections to slow due to the price uptick and resulting premium to the forward months.
At Sumas, Wash., prices climbed one cent to the low-$1.40s per million British thermal units (mmBtu) following the uptick in the Alberta market.
Westcoast Energy's 750 million cubic feet a day Fort Nelson gas plant in northeastern B.C., is expected to return to service later this week following a maintenance outage.
In eastern Canada, prices at Niagara rose four cents to about $2.35-2.36 per mmBtu on the heels of the rising futures.
Temperatures in Toronto were forecast to reach highs in the mid-70s over the next two days, according to Weather Services Corp, which will likely keep cooling demand at a minimum.
